. Hey Luca,
I agree with your evaluation in general, let me address it point by point:
1. The reason I load the entire font rather than a stripped down version is customization. You can customize both the text on the button and the icon used to the left if you want. Because of this, if I stripped the font to just those letters and only that icon, you lose the ability to change things if you want.
2. This is not feasible without again killing customization options. Since you get to choose the class, colors, etc. on your share button, this info is rendered dynamically into the stylesheet, which means that it needs to be touched by JS before render. For this reason, it's processed through a javascript function that makes sure the classes, colors, etc, are all correct at runtime then injected inline. If you want to see the styles, you can just look at the source, or use the inspector in your browser of choice to see what classes are on the element as you usually would - I don't think it would make it any easier to have them in a separate stylesheet, and it certainly would not make it faster.
So I guess what I would say overall is that while you are correct that making the changes you mentioned would make the button lighter (although certainly not more modular), it would also kill all the flexibility built in and only allow you to use the button in it's default state or face some weird issues.
That being said, I don't think that's such a bad thing. I think most people do use it in it's default state -- I certainly do -- and I think it would be a great idea to make a third build of the button that was as slim and inflexible as possible for the situations where you need that. As kyle mentioned above, if you do want to take a stab at this and submit a pull request that would be awesome, and we would be very likely to accept it. I would just say rather than overwriting the button as it exists now, have it built out to an alternate from the cakefile so we can offer it as an option :grinning: .

- If you have a button that says "SHARE" in clear capital letters, it seems counter-intuitive to me that someone would like your content enough to share it, intend to share it by clicking that button, then once they see the networks go "Shit I have to click again? This is way too much work, fuck it" and not share the page.
- A bunch of share buttons on a page is spammy-looking and visually distracting. Compressing them into a button frees up visual real estate on your page and makes it look more elegant and less spammy.
- When you hide the networks behind a button, you can load the page much quicker, as mentioned previously, and load less of the networks' tracking scripts and other bullshit without the user intending for that to happen.
These are totally opinions backed by zero research at all. If someone did research on this, it would be awesome, I'd be interested to see the result. I agree with your evaluation in general, let me address it point by point:
1. The reason I load the entire font rather than a stripped down version is customization. You can customize both the text on the button and the icon used to the left if you want. Because of this, if I stripped the font to just those letters and only that icon, you lose the ability to change things if you want.
2. This is not feasible without again killing customization options. Since you get to choose the class, colors, etc. on your share button, this info is rendered dynamically into the stylesheet, which means that it needs to be touched by JS before render. . Yeah, I see what you are saying for sure. But the entire point of this project is to have it require an additional click. Our general view on this is that if people want to share your page, they will do so, and we trade an additional click for the following benefits: 
- If you have a button that says "SHARE" in clear capital letters, it seems counter-intuitive to me that someone would like your content enough to share it, intend to share it by clicking that button, then once they see the networks go "Shit I have to click again? This is way too much work, fuck it" and not share the page.
- A bunch of share buttons on a page is spammy-looking and visually distracting. Compressing them into a button frees up visual real estate on your page and makes it look more elegant and less spammy.
- When you hide the networks behind a button, you can load the page much quicker, as mentioned previously, and load less of the networks' tracking scripts and other bullshit without the user intending for that to happen.
These are totally opinions backed by zero research at all. If someone did research on this, it would be awesome, I'd be interested to see the result. But with all that being said, using this library is a trade-off -- one some people are willing to make and others are not. For those who are not, they typically choose not to use this library. But we are, which is why we made and use it.

. Just to chime in; in share-button's current state we've added the ability for users to integrate the button in various ways and allow a lot more customization than previous versions. Regarding how lightweight share-button is, well that's left to one's opinion. I do agree that it's current state isn't the lightest, but some people will consider jquery to be light and that's pretty big. Tho in the end we have trade-offs, the reason we jumped in size so much between  v0.5.0 & v1.0.3 is due to the switch from coffeescript & babel, this is due to everything that goes into transpiling. If you wanted the lighter version, I'd recommend going with v0.5.0, but be aware that it comes with the downside of less customization. In the future I'd like to have the ability to have a couple options for building share-button, like no polyfills or removal of collision-detection, these were features that the community requested, but not everybody uses them. In the end if you want to cut down on everything, you have the ability to customize the button and completely remove lato, you just need to clone it down and compile your changes :smile:

| share-button.js | 65 KB |

| --- | --- |

As well the encoding of the SVG markup in the background-image URL doesn't look good. 
The normal SVG markup code be used, like this:
background-image: url("data:image/svg+xml;utf8, <svg>...</svg>");
. @hhsnopek @rcamposp It appears that omitting utf8 isn't the actual problem. 
In Chrome, not explicitly setting the width and height of the SVG element causes it to not work. 
Here's an example with the same code being used on the page with the problem:
http://jsbin.com/wuyemu/edit?html,css,output
Setting the width and height may work. 
Interestingly Mozilla Firefox doesn't seem to support non-encoded SVG, but using the URI encoded SVG is the option to go for.

unRARed:
I just ran into this same issue this evening. It appeared the solution was going to be having to download the assets and refer to them explicitly, but strangely I was able to get the assets to display as is with only these two lines of SASS:
sass
share-button .sb-social ul li:before
  background-image: url()
Can't confirm vanilla CSS will do the trick but the above compiles to:
css
share-button .sb-social ul li:before {
  background-image: url();
}
Confirmed working in Safari Version 9.1.1 (11601.6.17), Firefox 47.0 and Chrome 51.0.2704.103.
